title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Set off to see my mother before dinner: found she had not been so well during my absence. In consequence of the distance of Crampton's house from Abbey Street, resolved  to return to my old quarters at Bllson's. Comjiany at dinner at Crampton's : Sir C. and Lady Morgan, John Doherty, the Corrys, Colonel Shawe, &c. Crampton told me that he had shown my lines about " the Bishop and the Bold Dragoon " to Lord Wellesley ; and on the lines " To whom no harlot comes amjss, save her of Babylon," Lord W. said, " Well, I make no exception to the general rule, for she does not come amiss to me either."^ Additional company in the evening: IVIrs.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: 19th. Awake at a little after four ; got up at half-past five, and was in Abbey Street at half-past six. The priest not yet come ; at seven he arrived, and we had mass in the room with the coffin.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Have drawn upon the Longmans,  through him, for 100/., 70/. of which I have spent in expenses, and in paying bills for Abbey Street. God only knows (I again and again say) how I am to get through the difficulties that are before me.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Went to INIrs. Legh's afterwards, and from thence with Ellen to Abbey Street, where I found John (who had arrived to-day), and supped.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Took my time at breakfast, and waited for Ellen's note, but none came. Walked down to Abbey Street, and found that all was over ; my dear father had died at seven in the morning. Consulted about the funeral, which it was the wish of all to have as simple and private as possible  : entrusted the management of it to Mr. Legh, the son of an old friend of my mother.

title: A bachelor's rambles through the British Isles.
author: Butler, Charles J.
snippet: He remarked that several had been mistaken like myself, seeing him at a distance. In the afternoon, attended the Sabbath school of the Lower Abbey Street Wesleyan Chapel. The superintendent requested me to teach a class of young lads, and after teaching the lesson, I gave them an account of Sunday school work in America.
